content: Obama once said to change your oil in your vehicles and that would help solve the energy problem and lower gas prices. Now his new idea he is passing on to his disciples is to paint your roofs white to end global warming. I can feel the change a coming folks. LONDON(AFP) (AFP) - US Energy Secretary Steven Chu said Tuesday the Obama administration wanted to paint roofs an energy-reflecting white, as he took part in a climate change symposium in London. The Nobel laureate in physics called for a "new revolution" in energy generation to cut greenhouse gas emissions. But he warned there was no silver bullet for tackling climate change, and said a range of measures should be introduced, including painting flat roofs white. Making roads and roofs a paler colour could have the equivalent effect of taking every car in the world off the road for 11 years, Chu said. It was a geo-engineering scheme that was "completely benign" and would keep buildings cooler and reduce energy use from air conditioning, as well as reflecting sunlight back away from the Earth. For people who found white hard on the eye, scientists had also developed "cool colours" which looked to the human eye like normal ones, but reflect heat like pale colours even if they are darker shades. And painting cars in cool or light colours could deliver considerable savings on energy use for air conditioning units, he said. Speaking at the start of a symposium on climate change hosted by the Prince of Wales and attended by more than 20 Nobel laureates, Chu said fresh thinking was required to cut the amount of carbon created by power generation. He said: "The industrial revolution was a revolution in the use of energy. It offloaded from human and animal power into using fossil fuels. "We have to go to a different new revolution that can severely decrease the amount of carbon emissions in the generation of energy."

These mothers, instead of being able to work for their honest livelihood, are forced to employ all their time in strolling to beg sustenance for their helpless infants: who as they grow up either turn thieves for want of work, or leave their dear native country to fight for the Pretender in Spain, or sell themselves to the Barbadoes. content: Well, if you actually take the time to read this: ""http://junkscience.com/MSU_Temps/Warming_Proxies.html You'll find that the answer depends on which premesis you start with. Frankly, after an awful lot of reading and direct observation of the "real world" , my opinion is that anthropogenic warming is mistaken. That even if "true" the effects of warming are so gradual that any changes will be dealt with easily, almost un noticed. HOWEVER, no matter anthropogenic or natural, in a few thousand years, we're back in the deep freeze. and THAT's going to be a terrable time for humanity.

content: The new flurescent lamp bulbs are of very poor quality. They have burned out as quickly as incandescents. The "old" lamp fluroscents lasted me a decade of near constant use. I agree that limiting your expenses by lowering useage makes sense, but increasing taxes so energy costs MORE is stupid.

Now his new idea he is passing on to his disciples is to paint your roofs white to end global warming. I can feel the change a coming folks. LONDON(AFP) (AFP) - US Energy Secretary Steven Chu said Tuesday the Obama administration wanted to paint roofs an energy-reflecting white, as he took part in a climate change symposium in London. The Nobel laureate in physics called for a "new revolution" in energy generation to cut greenhouse gas emissions. But he warned there was no silver bullet for tackling climate change, and said a range of measures should be introduced, including painting flat roofs white. Making roads and roofs a paler colour could have the equivalent effect of taking every car in the world off the road for 11 years, Chu said. It was a geo-engineering scheme that was "completely benign" and would keep buildings cooler and reduce energy use from air conditioning, as well as reflecting sunlight back away from the Earth. For people who found white hard on the eye, scientists had also developed "cool colours" which looked to the human eye like normal ones, but reflect heat like pale colours even if they are darker shades. And painting cars in cool or light colours could deliver considerable savings on energy use for air conditioning units, he said. Speaking at the start of a symposium on climate change hosted by the Prince of Wales and attended by more than 20 Nobel laureates, Chu said fresh thinking was required to cut the amount of carbon created by power generation. He said: "The industrial revolution was a revolution in the use of energy. It offloaded from human and animal power into using fossil fuels. "We have to go to a different new revolution that can severely decrease the amount of carbon emissions in the generation of energy."

Poor Black and Hispanic people should not have kids. Same is true of oriental people. Gay people are fine as long as they adopt kids that have been cloned from highly educated women. I know I know there are not that many of them out their but we have to find them. Sending a few Nukes into North Korea, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Vietnam, Mexico, Peru, and Saudi Arabia would help also. You're suggestion was put forth in greater detail almost three hundred years ago, but with a more "postive" solution... quote: A Modest Proposal For Preventing The Children of Poor People in Ireland From Being Aburden to Their Parents or Country, and For Making Them Beneficial to The Public By Jonathan Swift (1729) It is a melancholy object to those who walk through this great town or travel in the country, when they see the streets, the roads, and cabin doors, crowded with beggars of the female sex, followed by three, four, or six children, all in rags and importuning every passenger for an alms. These mothers, instead of being able to work for their honest livelihood, are forced to employ all their time in strolling to beg sustenance for their helpless infants: who as they grow up either turn thieves for want of work, or leave their dear native country to fight for the Pretender in Spain, or sell themselves to the Barbadoes. "http://art-bin.com/art/omodest.html" Dave

content: quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by 3678131: Duster6; I read about this yesterday and just the truth is we have no control over the weather.. Whether global warming is real or imagined, haven't you noticed that there is an energy crunch? We could save a couple of billion barrels of oil simply by switiching from incandescent to flourescent bulbs. There are in fact hundreds of little things, which involve no hardship, and yet could save BIG BUCK$. Why it's necessary to make fun of these steps is beyond me. Dave Switching to flourescent may say energy, but they give my wife migraines. I would rather have a happy wife and higher energy bills then a *****y wife and lower bills.

content: Well, if you actually take the time to read this: ""http://junkscience.com/MSU_Temps/Warming_Proxies.html You'll find that the answer depends on which premesis you start with. Frankly, after an awful lot of reading and direct observation of the "real world" , my opinion is that anthropogenic warming is mistaken. That even if "true" the effects of warming are so gradual that any changes will be dealt with easily, almost un noticed. HOWEVER, no matter anthropogenic or natural, in a few thousand years, we're back in the deep freeze. and THAT's going to be a terrable time for humanity.

And when will they improve them so they light quickly when cold such as outside or an unheated garage/barn/shed, etc.?

content: The new flurescent lamp bulbs are of very poor quality. They have burned out as quickly as incandescents. The "old" lamp fluroscents lasted me a decade of near constant use. I agree that limiting your expenses by lowering useage makes sense, but increasing taxes so energy costs MORE is stupid.
reply: The new flurescent lamp bulbs are of very poor quality. They have burned out as quickly as incandescents. The "old" lamp fluroscents lasted me a decade of near constant use.
